The Bazooka is the last non-siege ranged unit. It is the most powerful ranged unit. Despite having only a one-hex range it can still deal significant damage to other units without being hurt itself. This makes it a great defense unit.

This mounted unit replaces Cavalry and is a fierce warrior in the deserts of Morocco. Receives combat bonuses for both fighting in a Desert tile or fighting in Moroccan territory (these bonuses do stack).
Replaces the Ironclad for the Germans. It has a higher combat strength which gives it a greater ability to influence city states.
This melee unit earns points toward starting the next Carnival for Brazil when it defeats an enemy. Use them to fight wars in foreign lands to push Brazil toward a Culture victory.

The Cataphract is a Byzantine unique unit, replacing the Horseman. Cataphracts are slower but more powerful than the Horseman unit, making them one of the most dangerous cavalry units until the arrival of the Knight. They can move after attacking. They are able to gain defensive bonuses, unlike the Horseman. Also their penalty for attacking cities is not as severe.

Only the Byzantines may build this unit. Attacks with lethal Greek Fire, making it the first naval unit with a ranged attack. This unit fights at +50% strength against other naval units. It cannot enter Deep Ocean tiles outside of the city borders.
Replaces the Ironclad for the Italians. Receives the coastal raider promotion which increases its strength against cities.

A Caravan allow you to establish a land-based Trade Route between two civilizations, earning [ICON_GOLD] Gold for both the owner and the destination civilization. Building a Granary or a Workshop in its home city also allows you to shuttle [ICON_FOOD] Food or [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production among your own cities. Once you assign it to a route, it cannot defend itself, so make sure the route is clear of danger.

The Caravel is a significant upgrade to a civilization's naval power. A Melee unit, it is stronger and faster than a Trireme, and it can enter Deep Ocean hexes. It is quick, giving it a promotion that gives it a good chance to withdraw to the rear before an enemy naval melee attack can occur. The Caravel has an enhanced sight radius, making it the eyes and ears of the mid-game navy. This sight bonus is lost if the Caravel is upgraded to a Destroyer.

A Cargo Ship allows you to establish a sea-based Trade Route between two civilizations, earning [ICON_GOLD] Gold for both the owner and the destination civilization. It also has a much longer range than the land-based Caravans. Building a Granary or a Workshop in its home city also allows you to shuttle [ICON_FOOD] Food or [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production among your own cities. Once you assign it to a route, it cannot defend itself, so make sure the route is clear of danger.

The African Forest Elephant is a Carthaginian unique unit, replacing the Horseman. The Carthaginian Elephants are slower but more powerful than the Horseman. They can move after attacking. They also strike fear into nearby enemy units, giving them all a negative combat modifier. Success in combat with an Elephant has an increased chance of generating Great Generals.

Only the Carthaginians may build this unit. It is a stronger version of the Trireme, including in Combat Strength. Like the Trireme it is a melee attack unit, engaging units at sea or cities (but it has no ranged attack). The Quinquereme cannot enter Deep Ocean tiles outside of the city borders.
The Cavalry mounted units are devastating against melee, ranged and siege weapons. Use them to destroy Musketmen and then break through the enemy's lines with their ability to move after attacking.

The Pictish Warrior is the Celt unique unit. Perfectly suited for early rushes, a Pictish Warrior can lay waste to an opponents' lands, quickly pillaging and moving within the same turn. Additionally, they earn [ICON_PEACE] Faith for each unit they kill, constantly advancing your religious goals while at war.

The Clibanarii is the Sassanid unique unit and replaces the Horseman. While its Combat Strength, Defense and efficiency against cities are higher than that of the Horseman, it can not move as far. As a Mounted Unit it is vulnerable to attacks by Spearmen, Pikemen and the like. It starts with the Blitz promotion, allowing it to attack twice in the same turn, and like other mounted units, it can move after attacking.

The Composite Bowman is more powerful than the Archer. As a Ranged unit it can deal significant damage to other units up to two hexes away, but it is vulnerable to melee attack. Put Composite Bowman in your city for defense, and guard them with melee units when on the move.

The Crossbowman is more powerful than the Composite Bowman. As a Ranged unit it can deal significant damage to other Medieval Era units up to two hexes away, but it is vulnerable to melee attack. Put Crossbowmen in your city for defense, and guard them with melee units when on the move.
Egyptian Cavalry replacement. Its promotions allow it to spawn Great Generals faster and fight better in open terrain.

The Destroyer is a naval melee attack unit designed to hunt down and destroy submarines and to provide anti-aircraft support. It often operates as an escort to embarked units, battleships and carriers when in range of enemy planes and subs. It is quick, giving it a promotion that gives it a good chance to withdraw to the rear before an enemy naval melee attack can occur.
European archaeologist replacement. It can attack and defend unlike the archaeologist. It can also move through rough terrain as if the terrain was clear. It does not require a University.

Flyers have a short range and a moderate attack. They excel at hit and run tactics, especially against Airships and Sky Fortresses, which are too bulky to effectively dodge their strikes. Their limited range restricts them to mostly defensive roles at first, but later on the Sky Fortress can act as their mobile base, transporting them directly into the battlefield.

The Flyer began as an inventor's novelty, one of the many results of the widespread participation in science brought on by the Age of Steam. Advancements in propulsion had done wonders for land and sea vehicles; why not apply them in the pursuit of the eternal dream of human flight? The engine mounted on the fuselage was bulky, so every ounce of weight had to be saved if the plane was to fly. Cloth was used instead of metal wherever possible. Later, as technology advanced, weapons were mounted on it and liberties were taken with the original design.

Replaces the Rifleman for the Belgians. Receives the Rough Terrain Promotion which allows it to fight better in difficult terrain. This unit also has a promotion that increases its strength against wounded units.
Boer Republics Rifleman replacement. It is weaker than a normal rifleman attacking, but stronger defending. It also partially heals after killing its opponents.
Combat bonus from Fortification increases by [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]{1_UnitFortificationPercent}%[ENDCOLOR]

The Seaxman is the Frankish unique unit. It has a slightly higher Combat Strength than the Swordsman, which it replaces. Additionally it does not require any Iron resources. It starts with the Amphibious promotion, allowing it to attack from the ocean and across rivers without penalty.

The Foreign Legion is a special unit, only available through the Volunteer Army tenet of the Freedom Ideology. It receives a significant combat bonus when operating outside of home territory, making it an excellent unit to use to gain control of foreign lands.

The Foreign Legion is a French unique unit, replacing the rifleman. It receives a significant combat bonus when operating outside of home territory, making it an excellent unit to launch against enemy territory.

The Frigate is the first naval unit since the Caravel. Its Movement, Combat and Ranged Combat strengths are all enhanced when compared to the older naval unit. The Frigate can clear the seas of any Caravels, Triremes, and Barbarian units still afloat.

The Galleass is the first naval unit with a ranged attack generally available to the civilizations in the game. It is much stronger than earlier naval units but a bit slower. It cannot initiate melee combat. The Galleass is useful for clearing enemy ships out of shallow waters. It cannot enter Deep Ocean hexes unless it is from Polynesia.

The Galley is a Barbarian unit which remains in coastal hexes, looking for embarked units to destroy. It is far weaker than any other naval units, but can be dangerous in packs. It is a melee attack unit, engaging units at sea or cities (but it has no ranged attack).

The Gatling Gun is a mid-game non-siege ranged unit. It is much more powerful than earlier ranged units like the Crossbowman. It has only a one-hex range, but still can deal significant damage to other units without being hurt itself. Put Gatling Guns in your city for defense.

The Landsknecht is a unit only available through the Mercenary Army social policy that must be purchased with gold. The Landsknecht is much cheaper than the Pikeman and has a number of bonuses related to pillaging tiles and sacking cities. These units create a cheap army that can provide a nice return on their investment if sent rampaging across enemy territory.

The Panzer is the German unique unit, replacing the tank. It is both stronger and faster than the tank. It also can move after combat, allowing it to blow huge holes in enemy lines and then barrel through before the enemy can repair the gap.

The Gadrauht is the Gothic unique unit. It has a slightly higher Combat Strength than the Swordsman, which it replaces. Additionally it does not require any Iron resources. The Gadrauht may move along enemy roads as if they were friendly roads.

The Great Admiral has the ability to instantly repair every naval and embarked unit in the same hex, as well as in adjacent hexes. The Great Admiral is consumed when performing this action. The Great Admiral also provides a 15% combat bonus to all player-owned naval units within 2 tiles. The Great Admiral is NOT consumed when he provides this bonus.

A Great Artist can create a Great Work of Art (generates both [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism) that is placed in the nearest city that has an appropriate building with an empty slot (like the Palace, a Museum, or a Cathedral). A Great Artist can also create a Golden Age. Great Artists are expended when used either of these ways.

Great Engineers can construct the special Manufactory improvement, which, when worked, provides a lot of [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production for a city. The Great Engineer can also hurry production of a unit, building or Wonder in a city. The Great Engineer is expended when used in either of these ways.

The Great General can construct the special Citadel improvement which gives a big defensive bonus to any unit occupying it, damages enemy units moving adjacent, and puts all adjacent tiles into your territory. The Great General is consumed when it builds the Citadel. The Great General provides a 15% combat bonus to all player-owned land units within 2 tiles. The Great General is NOT consumed when he provides this bonus.

The Great Merchant can construct the special Custom House improvement which, when worked, produces loads of [ICON_GOLD] Gold. The Great Merchant can also journey to a city-state and perform a "trade mission" which produces gobs of [ICON_GOLD] Gold and garners many Influence Points with the city-state. The Great Merchant is expended when used in either of these ways.

A Great Musician can create a Great Work of Music (generates both [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism) that is placed in the nearest city that has an appropriate building with an empty slot (like an Opera House or Broadcast Tower). A Great Musician can also travel to another civilization and perform a Concert Tour, which will give you a one-time boost in [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism in that territory. Great Musicians are expended when used either of these ways.

The Great Prophet is the only unit who can found or enhance a religion. He can also construct the special Holy Site improvement which, when worked, produces lots of [ICON_PEACE] Faith. Alternatively, the Great Prophet can spread religion 4 times (displacing any previous religions in these cities). The Great Prophet is expended when used in any of these ways.

The Great Scientist can construct the special Academy improvement which, when worked, produces lots of [ICON_RESEARCH] Science. Further, the Great Scientist lets you immediately gain a large amount of science based on the science output of your civilization. The Great Scientist is expended when used in either of these ways.
Great War Infantry is the basic Modern era combat unit. It's significantly stronger than its predecessor, the Rifleman.

A Great Writer can create a Great Work of Writing (generates both [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism) that is placed in the nearest city that has an appropriate building with an empty slot (like an Amphitheater, National Epic, Heroic Epic, or Royal Library). A Great Writer can also write a Political Treatise, which grants the player a large amount of Culture. Great Writers are expended when used either of these ways.

The Helicopter Gunship is a deadly air unit that in most respects acts like any ground unit, except that it cannot capture cities. Its movement of 6 makes it extremely quick, and it can move over all terrain types including mountains as if they were clear, but it must embark to cross water. Gunships receive a hefty combat bonus when fighting tanks.
Excellent at exploring and fearsome in combat, this Shoshone Unique Unit replaces the Scout. It possesses a promotion that gives it [ICON_PEACE] Faith for discovering Natural Wonders.

Battering Rams are a Hunnic unique unit replacing the Spearman. Use Battering Rams to knock down the defenses of a city. They have the Cover I promotion to keep them safe from ranged units; attack them with melee units to defeat them.

Horse Archers are fast ranged units, deadly on open terrain. They are slightly stronger in defense than the Chariot Archer and can move through rough terrain without the Chariot Archer's movement penalty. They also start with the Accuracy I promotion. As a mounted unit, the Horse Archer is vulnerable to Spearmen. Unlike the Chariot Archer, the Horse Archer does not require Horses.

The Scourge of God is a Hun Unique Great Person, replacing the standard Great General. The same combat bonuses apply, but the Scourge moves at a faster rate and can heal adjacent units for an additional 20 HP per turn. This enhanced General ensures that his cavalry units will always be in a battle-ready state.
The Kris Swordsman replaces the standard Swordsman. Try him out in combat as soon as possible to unlock the secret properties of his curvy Kris blade.

Infantry is significantly stronger than its predecessor, the Great War Infantry. Modern combat is increasingly complex, and on its own an Infantry unit is vulnerable to air, artillery and tank attack. When possible Infantry should be supported by artillery, tanks, and air (or anti-air) units.

Can be purchased with [ICON_PEACE] Faith in any city with a majority Religion that has been enhanced. They can remove other religions from your cities (expending the Inquisitor) or be placed inside a city to protect it from Missionaries and Prophets trying to spread other religions into that city.

Ironclads are the first steam-powered warships available. Fighting as a naval melee unit, they are harder to kill than any sailing vessel, and their Combat strength is higher. Use them primarily for in-shore defense and to assault cities.

The Samurai are the Japanese unique unit, replacing the Longswordsman. As powerful as the Swordsman, the Samurai automatically receives the "Shock I" promotion, giving it a bonus when fighting in open terrain. Success in combat with a Samurai has an increased chance of generating Great Generals. Can build fishing boats without being consumed.

The Zero is the Japanese unique unit, replacing the Fighter. The Zero is a moderately-powerful air unit. It is like the standard fighter, except that it gets a significant combat bonus when battling other fighters and [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]does not require the Oil resource[ENDCOLOR]. It can be based in any city you own or aboard an aircraft carrier. It can move from city to city (or carrier) and can perform "missions" within its range of 8 tiles. See the rules on Aircraft for more information.

The Lancer is the Renaissance horse unit that comes between the Knight and the Cavalry unit. It's faster and more powerful than the Knight, able to sweep those once-mighty units from the map. The Lancer can even take on the powerful Cavalry unit once it appears.

The Landship is heavily armored and excels at ground combat. Use it to defeat other land units and wear down cities for capture. Its armor will help protect it against the smaller guns of Flyers, but it is vulnerable to cannon fire from Airships. Escort the Landship with units that are strong against air units, such as Flyers and Anti-Air Guns, for maximum survivability.

The Landship was everything the land ironclad was to be but was not. The discovery of luboric increased the energy available to power such a vehicle exponentially, allowing for more armor and weaponry while maintaining the same maneuverability. It became the gold standard on the battlefield, capable of destroying nearly any other land unit. With several of them, a commander could quickly take out an army or encircle a city.

The most basic type of landship unit, the Land Ironclad is well armored and shines in ground combat. Use it to easily defeat primitive land units and wear down cities for capture. Its armor will somewhat protect it against the smaller guns of Flyers, but it is very vulnerable to cannon fire from Airships.

Much had been learned from the construction of the "Iron Horse" that was the railroad. Soon, inventors tried to engineer a vehicle with the power of a locomotive without need of a track. Designing the apparatus for moving the unwieldy metal beasts that were the first prototypes proved extremely difficult. The process merged into a simpler design with much less armor plating, but enough to withstand gunfire and the elements. The first drivers found that having a light, maneuverable craft was much more effective than a bulky one. It allowed for quick travel on less fuel, as well as agility in combat.

The Land Leviathan is the pinnacle of landship units, bringing devastation to any other land unit. Use it to destroy vulnerable enemy Anti-Air Guns and ensure your air units stay safe. Its armor will help protect it against the smaller guns of Flyers, but it is still vulnerable to cannon fire from Airships and Sky Fortresses. It is best to protect the expensive Land Leviathan with units that are strong against air units, such as Flyers and Anti-Air Guns.

The Land Leviathan is the pinnacle of ground combat. Taking its name from the fantastic sea monster, it boasts immense firepower. It can fire from almost any angle and trek across the land at great speeds. It is outfitted with a crew of sixteen: some man the cannons, others tend the luboric engine, and a pair act as pilot and navigator. During training they learn to move and think as one unit, developing a shorthand language for giving complex commands quickly.

The Longswordsman is the standard medieval infantry combat unit. It is more powerful than the Knight, but much slower. It also outclasses the Pikeman, but doesn't receive that unit's bonus versus mounted units. Use Longswordsmen and Catapults to attack enemy cities.

The Machine Gun is the penultimate non-siege ranged unit. It is more powerful than earlier ranged units. Like the Gatling Gun it has only a one-hex range, but still can deal significant damage to other units without being hurt itself. It is vulnerable to melee attack. Put Machine Guns in your city for defense.
The Marine is an alternative to Infantry. It costs a bit more than Infantry but possesses promotions that enhance its Sight and attack strength when embarked at sea.

The Atlatlist is the Mayan unique unit, replacing the Archer. Atlatlists are both cheaper than a traditional Archer, and available earlier without having to research Archery. This early game advantage allows other research priorities to come into play.

Mehal Sefari are the backbone of the Ethiopian army. They start with promotions that give them bonuses fighting in rough terrain and near their capital. They are slightly cheaper to build than the Rifleman that they replace.

Can be purchased with [ICON_PEACE] Faith in any city with a majority Religion. Once adjacent to a city they can spread their religion to it (expending the Missionary after the second use). If a Missionary enters another civilization without Open Borders, their Religious Strength is reduced each turn. Once their Religious Strength reaches zero, they are destroyed.
Modern Armor is just like its predecessor, the Tank, only more-so. Modern Armor is much stronger than the Tank unit and possesses all the Tank's abilities, such as moving after combat.

The Musketman is the first gunpowder unit in the game, and it replaces all of the older foot-soldier types - Longswordsmen, Pikemen, and the like. It is not a ranged unit, however, and cannot attack an enemy that is more than one hex away.
Mystic Warrior
Used to remove other religions from cities. May only be obtained by purchasing with [ICON_PEACE] Faith. [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Does not require maintenance.[ENDCOLOR]

The Pathfinder is the Scout replacement, and only the Shoshone may build it. It explores as well as a Scout and fights almost as well as a Warrior. It gives a [ICON_PEACE] Faith bonus for discovering Natural Wonders. Costs more than a Scout.
The Norman Knight is the Norman Unique Unit, replacing the standard Knight. This Unit is the standard Knight augmented with the Blitz promotion, allowing it to attack more than once per turn.

The Nuclear Submarine is tougher and stronger than the earlier model. It too is invisible to most units and can see other submarines. Most importantly, Nuclear Submarines can carry guided missiles and nuclear missiles. Like submarines, Nuclear Subs are vulnerable to enemy Destroyers, Missile Cruisers, and Subs, so send units of your own out ahead to make sure the coast is clear.

The Paratrooper is a late-game infantryman. It is somewhat weaker than a mechanized infantry unit; however, it can parachute up to 9 tiles away (when starting in friendly territory). This allows the paratrooper to literally jump over enemy positions and destroy road networks, pillage vital resources and so forth, wrecking havoc behind his lines. The Paratrooper is at great risk when on such missions, so make sure the target is worth it!

The Winged Hussar is the Lancer replacement, and only the Polish may build it. Faster and more powerful than the Lancer, the Winged Hussar forces a defender to retreat when it inflicts more damage than it receives. A defender who cannot retreat instead takes extra damage.

This melee naval unit replaces the Caravel and is skilled at exploration. When it is in a tile next to land owned by another Civilization or City-State you are at peace with, it may perform a one-time trade mission to earn [ICON_GOLD] Gold and XP. The further the land is from your own capital, the greater the bonus, so it is best to use on distant players. Use this unit to explore the map and uncover the locations of other players.

Naval Unit that attacks as a melee unit. Starts with the first Coastal Raider promotion allowing it to earn gold from attacking coastal cities. May capture any enemy naval units it defeats as prize ships.
A siege unit that is in between a cannon and artillery. It has a 3 range , must set up, and is stronger than a canon. It cannot see as far as other units, and should be protected with other units.

The Huscarl is the Unique Unit for Anglo-Saxon England, replacing the Longswordsman. This Unit gains the Cover I and Bonus vs. Mounted (50) promotions for its ability to create shield walls when faced with attack.

Naval Unit used to specializes in attacking coastal cities to earn gold and capturing enemy ships. Only the Dutch may build it. Heals outside friendly territory. Starts with the first two Coastal Raider promotions allowing it to earn gold from attacking coastal cities. May capture any enemy naval units it defeats as prize ships.
The Comanche Riders replaces the Cavalry, and only the Shoshone may build it. Cheaper and faster than the base unit.

The Pathfinder is the Scout replacement, and only the Shoshone may build it. It explores as well as a Scout and fights almost as well as a Warrior. It allows the player to choose the benefit when uncovering an ancient ruin. Costs more than a Scout.

The Sky Fortress is the most advanced type of airship unit, and houses significant firepower. Not only can it use its cannons to attack land targets and other airships, but also it can act as a mobile base for a Flyer. With a Flyer running strikes on nearby airship units, the Sky Fortress poses a serious threat to many types of units, but is still vulnerable to enemy Flyers and Anti-Air Guns.

The majestic Sky Fortress is quite a sight to behold. Much larger than the airship, it casts a wide shadow on the ground below that strikes fear into the hearts of foes. It is outfitted with heavy weaponry, but kept aloft through advanced applications of aetherium's lift properties. Inside the ship's body are a variety of accommodations: war rooms used by generals above the battlefield, a small hangar which can host a squadron of Flyers, and even parlors for recreation. The Sky Fortress became the centerpiece of airship fleets, a mobile command center that could rain death on the land below and blow enemy airships out of the sky.

This is a Songhai unique unit, replacing the Knight. This unit has the same statistics as the Knight, but it is significantly better at attacking cities. The Mandekalu Cavalry can move after attacking. Its speed makes it difficult for an enemy to build a defensive line before the Mandekalu Cavalry reaches the target.

The Submarine is a specialized ship-killing vessel. It is invisible to most units - except for Destroyers, Missile Cruisers, and other Submarines - until it attacks, or is adjacent to another unit. The Submarine can enter ice hexes. Use the Submarine to patrol enemy waters and sink enemy ships, and to guard your own ships against attacks from enemy subs.
Caroleans are the backbone of the early Industrial era Swedish army. They start with the March promotion that allows it to Heal every turn, even if it performs an action.

Hakkapeliitta are the elite mounted units of the late Renaissance Swedish army. Stack a Great General with them if possible. The Great General receives the movement allowance of the Hakkapeliitta if they start the turn stacked. In addition, the Hakkapeliitta receive a 15% combat bonus when stacked with a Great General.
The Tank is an extremely powerful and mobile land unit. It can move after combat, allowing it to blow holes in enemy lines and then move into the now-vacant hexes.

The Triplane is an early air unit. It can be based in any city you own or aboard an aircraft carrier. It can move from city to city (or carrier) and can perform "missions" within its range of 5 tiles. Use triplanes to attack enemy aircraft and ground units, to scout enemy positions, and to defend against enemy air attacks. See the rules on Aircraft for more information.

The Trireme is the first naval unit available to civilizations in the game. It is a melee attack unit, engaging units at sea or cities (but it has no ranged attack). The Trireme is useful for clearing barbarian ships out of home waters and for limited exploration (it cannot enter Deep Ocean hexes outside of the city borders unless it is from Polynesia).

The Axeman is the Vandal unique unit. It has a slightly higher Combat Strength than the Swordsman, which it replaces. Additionally it does not require any Iron resources. It starts with the Charge promotion, giving it a combat bonus against damaged units.

The Trihemiolia is the Vandal unique naval unit. It has a higher Combat Strength than the Trireme, which it replaces, and is restricted to coastal tiles. It also comes with the promotion Supply, which enables it to heal outside of friendly territory, and is able to capture enemy ships. The Trihemiolias and the sum of its abilities make the Vandals a naval force to be reckoned with in the Mediterranean.
The Great Galleass is the Galleass replacement, and only the Venetians may build it. Has a stronger ranged attack, is more resilient in battle, and is more costly than the base Galleass.

The Merchant of Venice is a unique Great Merchant replacement. Aside from the normal Great Merchant abilities, the Merchant of Venice can acquire a City-State outright, bringing it under Venetian control as a puppet. The Merchant of Venice is expended when used in this way.

The Welsh Longbowman is a Celtic unique unit, replacing the Crossbowman. The Welsh Longbowman has a greater range than the Crossbowman, allowing it to attack enemies three hexes away, often destroying them before they can strike back. Like other ranged units, it is vulnerable to melee attack.

The Great War Bomber is an early air unit. It is effective against ground targets, less so against naval targets, and it's quite vulnerable to enemy aircraft. The Great War Bomber can be based on a player-owned city or aboard a carrier. It can move from base to base and perform missions within its range of "6." Use it to attack enemy units and cities. When possible, send in triplanes or fighters first to "use up" the enemy's anti-aircraft defenses for that turn. See the rules on Aircraft for more information.
The Landship is a powerful and mobile land unit. It can move after combat, allowing it to blow holes in enemy lines and then move into the now-vacant hexes.

The XCOM Squad is an elite team of soldiers based on the technology pioneered by the XCOM Initiative. When starting the turn in friendly territory this squad can be dropped up to 40 tiles away. Deploy these units into areas where the danger level is out of this world.
Before engaging in melee, the Impi performs a spear throw attack that can damage or kill the enemy unit before making contact. Only the Zulu may build it.

To win a Cultural Victory, you must become the dominant cultural influence in every civilization in the game. This is achieved through Tourism generated by Great Works that you create, and artifacts that you discover. The Tourism you generate has a constant impact on other civilizations, and its effect is amplified through Open Borders, Trade Routes, shared Religion and Ideologies, Research Agreements, etc.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When your cumulative Tourism output (for the entire game) surpasses the cumulative Culture output of each remaining civilization in the game, you win the Culture Victory.

Diplomatic Victory is achieved by winning a World Leader resolution in the World Congress. This is only possible once the World Congress becomes the United Nations.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]See the "World Congress" topic for more detailed information.
There are three paths to failure in Civilization V: losing all your cities, another civilization winning the game, or not having the highest score at 2050 AD.

If you capture a city that belonged to a conquered civilization or city-state, you have the chance to liberate that civilization or city-state, bringing them back into the game. This earns a large amount of admiration from the liberated player which can be leveraged for an attempt to win Diplomatic Victory. For a liberated city-state, you will gain a large amount of influence which goes towards securing them as your ally and gaining more delegates in the World Congress. For a liberated civilization, they will like you much more, and be much more likely to use their delegates to support you for World Leader.

Once the World Congress is founded, civilizations express their diplomatic power through the use of delegates. During each session of the World Congress, you assign these delegates to different resolutions that have different gameplay effects. Once the United Nations is founded, delegates are essential to becoming the World Leader and winning Diplomatic Victory.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]See the "World Congress" topic for more detailed information.

Great tomb complexes in the northwest of Ireland speak to the presence of people there since the glaciers retreated at the end of the last ice age. Irish legends tell that when the Tuatha De Dannan invaded the land and fought the Fir Bolg, they were so impressed by the Fir Bolg that they gave them a quarter of the island - the area that would become the kingdom of Connacht.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Unambiguous reference to the area begins around the 6th Century AD in the Annals of Ulster, marking the death of prominent lords of that realm. The Vikings arrived at Connacht at the start of the 9th Century, and around this time the ruling house of Connacht was founded by Conchobar mac Taidg Mor, and the O Conchobair ruled Connacht until the middle of the 15th Century. The rulers of Connacht were often at war with the other Irish kingdoms, as well as the British and the Vikings who were settling Ireland.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In Connacht, there are two mysterious megaliths - the Turoe Stone and the Castlestrange Stone, which are covered in carvings of a style and date commonly associated with mainland Europe during the Iron Age. The stones were likely brought to Ireland and moved over time, away from the successive waves of invaders who came to the land.

At the tip of Southwestern Scotland is the Gall-Ghaidhealaibh - the land of the foreign Gaels. Isolated by its rugged coastline and hilly northern border, it was nonetheless drawn on Ptolemy's map of Britain. The Romans called the inhabitants the Novantae, and the missionary Saint Ninian built a church here, but much of its history is shrouded in legend. The Welsh poets believed that one of King Arthur's Three Thrones of Britain was in Galloway, called Pen Rhionydd.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]At some point in the late 7th century, Galloway was wrestled from control of the Britons by the Kingdom of Bernicia, who displaced the locals from the flat arable land and forced them into the hills. But the remoteness of the region meant it was easy prey for the Vikings and the Irish (especially the Irish Vikings) for whom the territory was just a short hop across the Irish Sea.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Norse Gaels, the Gall-Gaedhil, are the best-known inhabitants of Galloway. The Norse controlled the Irish Sea, and their settlements dotted its edges. Despite their Gaelic that they shared with the nascent Scots, they were indisputably their own people, sailing from their isolated lands to wreak havoc on the coastlines of Britain. This isolation meant that the Lords of Galloway were effectively kings on their own until late in the Middle Ages, starting with Suibne mac Cineda in the early 10th century and extending until the 12th. Though nominally under the High King of Scotland, they could ignore or pay tribute to him as their power allowed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Law of Galloway lasted another two centuries after their Lords lost power, a tribute to the splendid isolation of the land and people of Galloway.

The Romans called the lands of the Ordovices, Gangani, and Deceangli "Venedotia," but the mountainous land on the Irish Sea was not a land under their control. As Roman power faded in Britain, the Kingdom of Gwynedd emerged, founded by the legendary Cunedda of Lothia. The land's name has been interpreted as meaning "Land of the War-Host," though the exact meaning is lost to time.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Gwynedd quickly became preeminent among the petty kingdoms of Wales. Maelgwyn the Tall in particular became the subject of many myths and legends, and was described by Gildas as one of the five greatest British Kings. Gildas also gave Maelgwyn a curious appellative - "Dragon of the Island" which may have morphed over time to "Pendragon" of literary fame. But Maelgwyn's death in 547 left a vacuum, and a series of succession wars followed. Gwynedd did ally with Powys to fight the Anglians in the early 6th century, and Cadwallon ap Cadfan launched a furious assault on the Northumbrians, sacking York in 633 and laying waste to the land. He and his son Cadwaladr Fendigad became the last two High Kings of Britain.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The house of Cunedda died off in the early 8th Century, and the house of Aberffraw (distantly related by ancestry) had to deal with incursions by the Vikings and Irish, ruling their subsidiary kingdom of Powys, and fighting with the other high Welsh families until they were overthrown by Howell the Good, who took the opportunity to straighten up the place and modernize it like those really progressive kingdoms in Wessex that had things like codified laws and their own money.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]By the Norman Invasion, Gwynedd had returned to fractious infighting amongst its nobles, and William the Conquer let his barons subjugate Wales as they could. But Norman authority held only tenuously in Gwynedd's high mountain lands and in the hearts of its people, who still remembered when they had been kings.

For 1000 years, Mide, or Meath, was the central Kingdom of Ireland, both geographically and spiritually. Tradition dates the founding of Meath to the First Century AD, by Tuathal Techtmar, ancestor of the great Niall of the Nine Hostages. Tuathal carved himself a kingdom from territory seized from Ulster, Leinster, Connacht, and Munster and named the resulting territory Meath. The Ui Neill kings of the South were the traditional rulers of Meath.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Meath's importance to the High Kings of Ireland was further enhanced because the Hill of Tara was situated there. The Hill of Tara is a complex of barrows and earthworks dating back to the Iron Age, and traditionally the place where the High King was crowned. The Hill of Tara has been used as a ritual location since the Neolithic, and was the spiritual heart of Ireland until the 12th Century, though its importance declined with the ascension of the British and the expansion of Christianity.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Whether or not the Irish High Kings sat in court on the Hill of Tara or not, Meath's central location in Ireland and its proximity to the Norse Irish settlements made it a kingdom of great importance. The Battle of Clontarf was fought on its soil, where the last great High King of Ireland, Brian Boru, fell.

Munster, in the southwest of Ireland, is one of the five great kingdoms of Ireland. In the second century, Ptolemy records the land as belonging to the Iverni tribe. According to legend, Bodb Derg was the second King of the Tuatha De Danann and the first of the Kings of Munster. The Eoganachta dynasty ruled from the 7th century, after the conquests of Failbe Flann mac Aedo Duib. The Eoganachta would in time become one of Ireland's most important clans, though they never became High Kings.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Vikings invaded starting in the 8th Century, and would in time found the cities of Cork, Waterford, and Limerick.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The last great High King of Ireland, Brian Boru, first proclaimed himself King of Munster before he was able to wrestle control of the kingship from the Ui Neill. His descendants, the O'Brians, were hereditary rulers of Munster as well, until the dissolution of the kingdom in the early 12th Century.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]By 1118, Munster had fractured into three smaller kingdoms: Thomond, Desmond, and Omond.

The adjoining kingdoms of Deira and Bernecia were united by force when King Aethelfrith of Bernicia conquered Deira in 604. But this victory was short-lived, and when Aethelfrith was killed in 616, the son of the former king of Deira, Edwin, was made king of the combined lands. But it was not until the rule of King Oswald in 634 that Northumbria was finally consolidated into a single Anglian kingdom. Oswald quickly expanded his kingdom and Christianized it with the help of Saint Aidan of Iona.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Northumbria was often at war with Mercia. Oswald was killed in battle with the Mercians in 650, and the Picts rose up and defeated the Northumbrians in 685. A brief period of stability under the reign of Aldfrith followed, but Northumbria had lost its prestige and power, and was conquered by the Danish brothers Halfdan Ragnarsson and the colorfully-named Ivar the Boneless. A brief uprising by Aella of Northumberland was brutally suppressed. Now subject to the Danelaw, a series of puppet kings ruled Northumberland until Erik Bloodaxe in 954. From then on, Northumberland was no kingdom, but a mere Earldom.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]William the Conquerer quickly set his eyes on Northumbria, recognizing it as a valuable buffer against the North, and as a symbol to resistance to his rule. He attempted to install one of his barons as an overlord, but the baron and 700 of his retainers were slaughtered in the city of Durham. This led William to conduct a punitive campaign into Northumbria, partitioning it into an Earldom seated in Durham, and the region of Northumberland. The Normans built the city of Newcastle to secure their hold on this new territory of theirs, but the hold was tentative. The lands of Northumbria were long afterwards a fractious border country, rebelling against rule from the south and fighting the protracted border war with the Scots to the North.

The Roman Empire marked out a territory in Britain between the Cambrian Mountains and Western Midlands, and built a capital at the site of modern Wroxeter called Viroconium Cornoviorum. As Roman power in Britain faded in the Dark Ages, a new state arose in the traditional lands of the Ordovices and Cornoviis, extending from the Cambrian Mountains to the Western Midlands. By the middle of the 5th Century AD, Powys was solidly established as a kingdom of Britain.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The first and greatest ruling house of Powys was the Gwerthrynion, who claimed the legendary Vortigern as their founder. The historical warlord Vortigern would later become the model for the literary King Arthur, and the literary embellishment of Arthur has done something to mythologize the kingdom of Powys as well.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Early in the 6th Century, Powys was ravaged by the Northumbrians and portions annexed by their erstwhile allies the Mercians, but Powys stormed back, conquering territory from the English until by mutual agreement a border was established at Offa's Dyke in the middle of the 7th Century. Offa's Dyke remains today the border between Wales and England.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Powys was eventually subsumed by the Kingdom of Gwynedd on the death of the last Gwerthyrnion king in 855. When Howell the Good became king of Gwynedd in 942, he already ruled most of the lands that make up modern Wales. Through savvy politicking and legal reforms, he made his kingdoms into great powers on the island, codifying Welsh Law and creating the first indigenous Welsh coin since the Bronze Age. On Howell's death, Powys was given to one of his sons, but the greater Welsh kingdom was reassembled by his grandson Maredudd ab Owain.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Over time, the power of the great Welsh families waned, and invaders from Ireland and the Vikings chipped away at the throne of Powys, as usurpers seized the throne and were overthrown by pretenders of the old houses. By the time of the Norman Invasion, constant fractious warfare wracked the land, and William the Conquerer was content to leave Wales to his barons to deal with. They in turn made a complete hash of it.

There have been people living in the north of Britain since the end of the last ice age, about 8,500 years before the Romans recorded works on the island. Neolithic ruins in Scotland predate the famous Skara Brae of the Orkneys, and archeological evidence reveals evidence of warring communities living in fortified villages through the Iron Age.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Caledonians fought hard and often successfully against the Romans in Britain, forcing them to retreat from their tentative forts and outposts behind Hadrian's Wall. The land was occupied by the Picts and Britons thereafter, until the Dark Ages, when the Irish, Anglo-Saxons, and then Vikings invaded and created permanent settlements in Scotland. Saint Ninian's mission brought Christianity to the region around 450 AD, although apparently the Picts then renounced it until Saint Columba arrived in 563.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Legend has it that the Picts were betrayed by the Scots king Kenneth Mac Alpin, who invited the Pictish king Drest and his nobles to a feast, plied them with drink, and then pulled the pins from their benches, sending them into spikey pits concealed beneath. The truth is somewhat less fanciful - Mac Alpin had claim to the crown of both kingdoms, and managed to combine them into what would become the Kingdom of Alba.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Kingdom of Alba became the core of what is recognized as Scotland. Through conquest and expansion, the kingdom of Strathclyde was added, and the southern barrier pushed to the River Tweed - the modern-day Southeastern border of Scotland.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]King Duncan led an expedition to try to seize the lands of his rival Macbeth around 1039. The expedition was a terminal disaster for Duncan, who was killed in battle, and Macbeth then became the king of the Scots. It should be noted that the conflict between Macbeth and Duncan was the basis for Shakespeare's play, and is historically accurate if you ignore such simple details as the age of both Duncan and Macbeth, the stated relationship between the two men, and the entire chronology given in the play. Duncan's son Malcolm did follow Macbeth as king of Scotland, so at least he got that part right. And as King James was Shakespeare's patron, a colorful reinterpretation of history that flattered the man paying the bills is perhaps understandable.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When William the Conquerer invaded Britain, Edgar the Aethling sought refuge in Scotland with an eye to claiming his kingship to the south, but by 1072 William had successfully invaded Scotland and forced Malcolm (who had become king in 1057) to pay him tribute and hostages.

Found in southern Spain, the Alhambra is a large palace complex of the Nasrid Dynasty, who controlled the region in the mid 14th century. Construction first began sometime around 1238 AD under the rule of Ibn al-Ahmar, and continued under his successors. Taking its name from the red hue of its walls, the name Alhambra is translated as the "Red Fortress." Noted for its Moorish Islamic architectural style, the Alhambra features elaborate engravings and numerous examples of the interlacing patterns known as "Arabesques" found predominately in Islamic art. Although many examples of the original Islamic style remain today, much of the palace and its interior was reconstructed and modified after the rise of Catholicism in Spain.

At one time the tallest free-standing structure in the world, the CN Tower of Toronto, Canada still remains among the tallest structures in the world today. Constructed in 1976 as a communications tower by the Canadian National Railway Company (hence the CN moniker), the tower has become a hallmark of Toronto and a major tourist attraction for the city. The tower is still primarily used for television and radio broadcasting, and is now considered one of the "Seven Wonders of the Modern World," joined by several notable constructions of the 20th century.

The Great Firewall is a restrictive internet monitoring and censorship program used to control the flow of information available to a civilization's people through the internet. By limiting the public's access to potentially volatile information available online, government agencies can limit potential backlash and other dissension regarding unpopular policies and government programs.

Named for renowned American astronomer Edwin Hubble, the Hubble Space Telescope has proven to be among the most crucial astronomical research tools ever developed. Launched in 1990, the telescope has continually provided breathtaking images of far-off constellations and nebulas, attracting widespread attention from both scientists and the general public. As the only space telescope capable of being repaired by astronauts, the service life of the Hubble has been continually extended through a series of space walks. However, despite its notable legacy, the Hubble Space Telescope will be replaced in 2018 by the more advanced James Webb Space Telescope.

Found in the Piazza del Duomo ("Cathedral Square") in the city of Pisa, Italy, the famous bell tower commonly known as the Leaning Tower of Pisa has stood slightly off-kilter for centuries. Construction on the tower began in 1173, and it quickly became clear that the unstable soil and minimal foundation upon which the tower was built were not enough to prevent it from sinking. After leaving the tower incomplete for nearly a century, construction resumed in the late 13th century, with the final level completed in 1372. The tower is home to seven bells, each comprising a different note on the musical scale.

Discovered in 2005 AD in southwest Ohio, the Moorehead Circle - a "woodhenge" - was constructed about 2000 years ago, between 40 BC and 130 AD, likely by one of the tribes in the Hopewell culture. Consisting of three concentric rings of wooden posts, estimated up to 15-feet tall each, some 200 in the outer ring that was about 200 feet in diameter, the Moorehead Circle was likely used for ceremonial purposes, although the specifics are unknown. Recently, a central alter filled with red earth with a 40-by-50 foot rectangular structure adjacent has been uncovered.

The largest mud-brick structure in the world, the Great Mosque of Djenne is found in the African Republic of Mali. Thought to have first been constructed sometime in the 13th Century by the sultan Koi Kunboro, the mosque has since been destroyed and rebuilt several times. The incarnation that stands today, assembled from mud bricks and mortar, was built in 1906 through the combined efforts of the surrounding community. Today, the mosque is maintained by the people of Djenne during an annual festival created specifically to ensure its longevity.

Commissioned by the "Mad King" Ludwig II of Bavaria in the late 19th century, the Neuschwanstein Castle has since become the symbol of iconic "fairy tale" castles commonly found in children's literature and fables. Built into a hillside near the town of Fssen in Germany, Ludwig had intended the castle to be his retreat from public view, as he was known for his reclusive nature. Following his death, the castle became a popular tourist attraction, and eventually served as the inspiration for the famous Sleeping Beauty Castle created by Walt Disney.

Constructed sometime around 1000 BC, the site of Petra in Jordan is among the most famous examples of rock-cut architecture in the world. Numerous intricately carved structures were cut into the sandstone walls of the desert canyons surrounding the area, as Petra came to serve as the capital city for the once-nomadic Nabataen people. The most famous of these structures, the Al Khazneh or "The Treasury," has been featured in numerous major motion pictures, notably a prominent role in "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade" when the Al Khazneh was used to represent the location of the Holy Grail.

Standing over 40 feet tall (12m), the Statue of Zeus found in the Temple of Zeus at Olympia, Greece was another of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. Known to have been constructed by the Greek sculptor Phidias c. 440 BC, even with Zeus seated on a golden throne, the enormous statue could barely be contained by the temple itself. The statue is thought to have been destroyed no later than 425 AD, when the temple of Zeus was burned. Whether the statue was still present at that time is the subject of much debate.

Unearthed by Chinese farmers in 1974, the Terracotta Army of Emperor Qin Shi Huang was assembled to accompany the emperor in his burial tomb. Constructed during the 3rd century BC, workers created thousands of life-sized earthen figures, with each soldier having unique characteristics added during their construction. Positioned in proper military formation along deep pits carved within the tomb, the soldiers of the Terracotta Army are joined by horses, chariots, and cavalry which were also replicated in great detail.

Dating back to the Postclassic Period of the Aztec Empire, adjacent to the capital of Texcoco, Texcotzingo served as the imperial summer gardens. Dedicated to Tlaloc, the god of rain, it was constructed by the monarch Nezahualcoyoti in the 15th Century AD. An elaborate and advanced irrigation system transformed Texcotzingo into a recreational paradise for the nobility, a display of the flora of the empire, a medicinal garden, and a sacred place. Covering 122 hectares, it is considered the first botanical garden of the world, and was a source of wonder for the Spanish conquistadors.
